lesson.name: Lesson 1: Preliminaries
lesson.intro:
Usually a lesson is due on the day when we will first cover the material, just before class.  But that won't work for Lesson 1 since there is  no way you will all have it done by 8:45 am on the  first day of class!  I have put the  due date for this on Sept. 14 at (somewhat arbitrarily) noon.  This puts its due date before Stage 1 of Assignment #1.  This is necessary since you won't have access to Assignment #1 unless you have done this lesson.

The real message here is that if you can get this done earlier than its due date that would be very beneficial to you.  I have put the due date as late as it is to help people ease into the term and figure out all the crazy deadlines in this course.

page.title: Reflect before you start
page.contents:
This lesson is called Preliminaries, because it is largely about ideas that are not really physics, but which you will need to know before we learn physics.  It will cover:

  • A brief overview some of the main ideas in the course.
  • The nature of measurement.
  • Measurement uncertainty.
  • How to analyze the statistics of a data set to draw conclusions about measurement uncertainty.
  • Vectors.

Before you start to look at any complicated content, whether it is a textbook, a set of video lectures, a web page, whatever, it is a good idea to prepare to learn by doing a bit of reflection.  To develop the habit it is good to write some reflections.  In the space below write three things (sentences, point form, whatever you want) about what you are about to learn.  Here are some things you might write about below:

  • List things that you think you might learn about in the lesson (in more detail than was given in the list above).
  • List things that you already know about the topics of this lesson.
  • List things that you have heard about these topics, but don't understand.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Main page - choose lesson part
page.contents:
You don't have to finish the lesson all in one sitting.  You can also retry it if you are not satisfied with how you did.  Here is a "map" of the lesson.  This is partly because moodle has a tendency (which I haven't figured out) to skip the Reflective Writing parts of these lessons.  This map will help you see if you have missed any and find your way to where they should be.

Choose one of the following lesson parts.  When you have finished that part of the lesson you will be brought back to this page.  When you have finished all parts of the lesson click the "OK, I'm done" button to end the lesson.

You don't have to watch the lectures in order, but lecture 3 will make more sense after lecture 2.  Also, there is something that you are asked to do after lecture 2 which you should have already done before you watch lecture 4.  So, overall, things will be simpler if you watch the lectures in the suggested order.

page.title: Conservation of Mass
page.contents: Water is boiling in a kettle.  The room that the kettle is in has no windows and the door is closed.  To a good approximation, which of the following quantities is conserved?

answer.answer_text: The total amount of water (liquid in kettle + vapour in room)
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: The amount of water in the kettle
answer.response: No.  As the water boils it evapourates and steam leaves the kettle.  We expect the amount of water in the kettle to be decreasing.

answer.answer_text: The amount of water vapour in the room
answer.response: No.  As steam leaves the kettle the amount of water vapour in the room should increase.

page.title: Online Lecture 1-1: Major Themes in the Course (Part 3)
page.contents: This is the last video about the major themes in the course.  Click to the next page (which will bring you back to the Main Menu this time) rather than letting YouTube autoplay.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Interpret mean, std. dev., SDOM
page.contents:
150 ppm
150 ppm
175 ppm
250 ppm
275 ppm

From the set of concentrations above we get the following statistics:

mean = 200 ppm
std. dev. ≃ 60 ppm
SDOM ≃ 30 ppm

Which statement is true?

answer.answer_text: The uncertainty in the best estimate is 30 ppm
answer.response: Yes, the SDOM is the uncertainty in the best estimate.

answer.answer_text: The uncertainty in each individual measurement is 30 ppm
answer.response: No.  The uncertainty in each measurement would be the standard deviation, not the SDOM.

answer.answer_text: The uncertainty in each individual measurement is 200 ppm
answer.response: No.  Does that make sense?  200 ppm is the "middle" of the data set.  That is where we expect the best estimate to be, so the mean is the best estimate.  The uncertainty should have to do with how "scattered" the data set is, which is not what the mean tells us.

answer.answer_text: The uncertainty in the best estimate is 60 ppm
answer.response: No.  60 ppm is the standard deviation, which is our estimate in the uncertainty in each individual measurement, not the uncertainty in the best estimate.

page.title: Online lecture 1-3: Working With Data (Part 3)
page.contents: Once we've carried out our statistical analysis we can write down a measurement with correct significant figures.  The main reason we go through this whole process is that it is necessary when we wish to compare two numbers to decide whether they are in agreement.  This video shows you how to do that.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: which equation is dimensionally correct? get t
page.contents: Working with standard symbols (x for positions, v for velocities, a for accelerations, t for times) which of the following equations is dimensionally correct?

answer.response: Yes. We get m/(m/s^2) = s^2 under the square root sign, which gives s.
No. The right, side of this equation has units of $$\sqrt{s}$$ but we want it to have units of s.
No. The right side of that equation has units of s^2, but we want it to have units of s.
No. The right side of that equation has units of s^-1, but we want it to have units of s.

page.title: Write measurement with correct sig. figs.
page.contents:
We have made 16 measurements of the acceleration due to gravity (g).  The mean of our measurements is 9.761734 m/s2.  The standard deviation of the measurements is 0.1843295 m/s2.

Which of the following is the correct way to write our final experimental value for g?

answer.response: Yes, you've correctly used the SDOM as the uncertainty and you have rounded correctly.

There are two problems with this answer. One is that you've used the standard deviation as the uncertainty in the mean. But you should use the SDOM (it wasn't given but you can easily calculate it). The second problem is that you are not correctly applying the significant figures rules.
You are rounding correctly. But you have used the standard deviation as the uncertainty when you should be using the SDOM. The SDOM wasn't given but you can easily calculate it.
You have (correctly) used the SDOM as the uncertainty. But you haven't applied the rules for significant figures correctly.

page.title: Online lecture 1-4: A First Look at Vectors (Part 2)
page.contents: We continue this quick introduction to vectors.  In this video we see the meaning of "components" and how to decompose a vector into its components in the simplest case.  We will see other methods for determining the components of a vector later.

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned
page.contents:
Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1104 - Response to Unit 1 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "First Half".  Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. In your own words, explain the difference between leading zeros and trailing zeros.  Which ones are significant figures?

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Online lecture 1-3: Working With Data (Part 1)
page.contents: In practice (such as in your labs) we use the statistics of our data to make decisions about significant figures.  This video begins to introduce you to these methods.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.

page.title: Identify this vector
page.contents:
Consider the vector in this diagram:

Which of the following is a correct way to write this vector?

answer.response: Yes.

No. That is a vector pointing from the origin to the tip of this vector. That is not what we mean by the vector itself. The components of a vector give information about how far the vector "carries you" in a direction parallel to each axis.
No, that is the position of the tip of the vector. But remember that if we move a vector this doesn't change its value. So writing down a vector has nothing to do with where its tip is.
Yes. We will generally use the notation \( 3\hat{i} -7\hat{j} \) in this course. But there is nothing wrong with writing it as \( (3,-7) \).
Almost. But the positive y-axis points up and walking this vector from tail to tip carries you downward.

No,the position of the tip of the vector is (4,1), which might be what you were looking at, except that in that case you reversed the x and y. But the position of the tip of the vector is not the same thing as the vector. Remember that if we move a vector this doesn't change its value. So writing down a vector has nothing to do with where its tip is.

page.title: give mag. dir. form
page.contents:
Get some practise.  Here is a vector and a coordinate system with a grid.

What are the magnitude and direction of this vector?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  You've forgotten how to use Pythagoras' Theorem to find the length of the hypotenuse of a triangle.

No, you are looking at where the end of the vector is (6,8) instead of looking at what the components of the vector are.  So you have used an x-component of this vector of 6.  However, the x-component of this vector is 4.
No.  Look at your calculator.  Is it in radian mode?

page.title: Which is 3a - 2b?
page.contents:
Given the vectors, \(\vec{a} \), and, \( \vec{b} \), below, which of the following is the best representation of \( 3\vec{a} - 2\vec{b} \)?

Note: If you answer incorrectly you will be given a hint and asked the question again.  The question will not let you go on to the next video until you get it right.

answer.response: Yes.
No. That is \( 3\vec{a} + 2\vec{b} \).
No. That is \( \vec{a} - \vec{b} \) (and it is also a confusing way to draw it).

No. The vectors which there are two of are not a correct representation of \( - \vec{b} \). It should be "flipped end for end" compared to \( \vec{b} \), but instead it has been reflected horizontally.
No. The vectors which there are two of are not a correct representation of \( - \vec{b} \). It should be "flipped end for end" compared to \( \vec{b} \), but instead it has been reflected vertically.

page.title: Online lecture 1-5: Vector Algebra (Part 1)
page.contents: In an earlier video you saw how to write down the components in a simple case where you know "how far the vector points" in each direction.  Most of the time we don't know this.  Most of the time we know the vector's magnitude, and an angle that it points from some other direction.  In this video we see how to calculate the components of a vector in that situation.

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned (final summary)
page.contents:
You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after the first half of the lesson.

Under what you wrote for the first half of the lesson write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. Suppose we have a vector, \( \vec{a} \) which points parallel to the x-axis.  Further, suppose that it could point in either the positive x-direction or in the negative x-direction.  In your own words, explain the difference between the vector, \( \vec{a} \), its magnitude, \( a \), and its x-component, \( a_x \).

You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

This video wraps up the topic of measurements and units by looking at how significant figures carry through calculations, and briefly introduces the topic of order of magnitude estimates.

There is a supplementary video with an example of an order of magnitude calculation. You will be doing order of magnitude estimates on all of your assignments, so you should definitely watch this supplementary video at some point.

page.title: add numbers with sig. fig. rule 2
page.contents:
Which of the answers below to the addition

142.16 kg + 3.743 kg

is written with the correct number of significant figures?

answer.response: Yes. 142.16 has two digits after the decimal whereas 3.743 has three digits after the decimal. So in this case the sig. fig. rule for addition says we should round the answer to two digits after the decimal.
No. We don't know the 3rd digit after the decimal place in 142.16 kg, so we can't know the 3rd digit after the decimal in the answer.

No. It is likely that either you are dropping the final "0" because you've been taught you "always can" or you are mixed up with the sig. fig. rule for multiplication. But in writing measurements we write all digits that we know, even if they are zero. The sig. fig. rule for addition tells us that we do know the 2nd digit after the decimal place, so we should write it, even though it is zero.
Why are you rounding to only three digits? This isn't consistent with any of the rules for sig. figs.
No. We don't know the 3rd digit after the decimal place in 142.16 kg, so we can't know the 3rd digit after the decimal in the answer.

page.title: Online Lecture 1-3: Working With Data (Part 2)
page.contents: This video gets further into how we use statistics to make decisions about the precision of our data by showing how we analyze our data to estimate its uncertainty. Part of this video shows pretty much exactly what you will be doing in part of the introduction to spreadsheets lab. So you may find it useful to watch this again while you are working on that lab.

answer.answer_text: Click here when you have finished watching the video.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Best Estimate
page.contents:
In an experiment, a scientist measures the concentration of contaminant in a sample 5 times. They obtain the set of measurements below.

150 ppm
150 ppm
175 ppm
250 ppm
275 ppm

What is the best estimate for the true value of the concentration of the contaminant?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  Did you choose it because it is the most common number in the list?  That is called the "mode" of the data.  But the best estimate is not the mode, it is the mean.
No.  Did you choose this because it is the "middle" value in the list?  That is the median.  But the best estimate is not the median, it is the mean.

Does that make sense?  The measurements are all between 150 and 275 ppm.  So why would 1000 be the most likely value for the true value?  I think you started to take the mean, but then forgot to divide by the number of data points.

answer.answer_text: No estimate can be obtained.  There is too much variation in the result.
answer.response: No.  When there is a lot of variation in the result it *may* indicate that the measurement process is not very reliable.  As we will see, this would result in the uncertainty being high.  But we can still obtain a best estimate.

page.title: Choose 2A + 4B (algebraic)
page.contents:
Suppose that

\( \vec{a} = 3 \hat{i} \) and \( \vec{b} = - 2 \hat{j} \)

Which of the following is \( 2\vec{a} + 4 \vec{b} \) ?

answer.response: Yes.
Did you drop a minus sign?
No.  That is the magnitude of \( 2\vec{a} + 4 \vec{b} \).  I didn't ask for the magnitude.  So the answer should be a vector.
No.  You have done a scalar addition of the (signed) sizes of the two vectors.  That's not how vector addition works.
No.  Did you not notice that one of the vectors points along the x-axis and the other points along the y-axis?

page.title: Online Lecture 1-2: Measurements and Units (Part 1)
page.contents: This video, and the next several videos, are mainly concerned with things that you will use in the lab part of the course.  As usual, when the video finishes playing, don't let YouTube autoplay and take you to the next video.  Click the button at the bottom of the page which will take you to the next page in the lesson.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Units for pressure
page.contents:
This question is just about unit analysis, so don't worry that some of the quantities we are using are unfamiliar.

You will encounter pressure in other courses, especially if you are in certain of the technology programs where you will take some fluids courses.  Here is one equation which gives a pressure (this is pressure within a stationary fluid)

\(\Delta P = \rho g h \)

where ΔP is a pressure change, ρ is a density (in kg/m3), g is an acceleration and h is a height (distance).  From this, determine the correct units of pressure in terms of base SI units.

answer.response: Yes. We have $$\frac{kg}{m^3} \frac{m}{s^2} s = \frac{kg}{m \cdot s^2$$

Yes, but that isn't in terms of base SI units. I suspect you either just knew that pressures are measured in Pa, or you googled the answer. If you googled it I'd just like to point out that you aren't helping your own learning by trying to look up answers to things that you are supposed to find yourself.

Yes, but that isn't in terms of base SI units. I suspect you either just knew that pressures are measured in N/m<sup>2</sup>, or you googled the answer. If you googled it I'd just like to point out that you aren't helping your own learning by trying to look up answers to things that you are supposed to find yourself.

Yuck! That isn't even metric. We are in an advanced nation that uses SI, not a primitive backwater (like a certain neighbour to the south) which still clings to antiquated units. Anyway, you couldn't have got that from the information given, so either you just knew that psi are a unit of pressure or you googled the answer. If you googled it I'd just like to point out that you aren't helping your own learning by trying to look up answers to things that you are supposed to find yourself.
No. Those are units of a force. Did you incorrectly cancel some of the meters?

page.title: Online Lecture 1-2: Measurements and Units (Part 2)
page.contents: This video gets further into issues of units, dimensional analysis, and significant figures.

answer.answer_text: Click this button when you have finished watching the lecture.
answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Timing friend running around track
page.contents:
Your friend runs once around a track.  You use a stopwatch to time them.  The stopwatch can be read to the nearest 0.01 s.  So, naively, the uncertainty in the timing is ± 0.005 s.  Do you believe that your measurement of their lap time is this precise?

Note: if you get the question wrong you will be given feedback and allowed to try again.  The question will not let you go on to the next part of the video until you answer correctly.

answer.answer_text: No. Other factors such as your reflexes will result in a larger uncertainty.
answer.response: Yes. Typical human reflexes would introduce an uncertainty into this timing of the order of a few tenths of a second. There are also issues of exactly how you judge when they passed the finish line (i.e. what part of their body crossing the line should trigger you to hit "stop" on the stopwatch?).

answer.answer_text: Yes, as long as you were careful doing the timing.
answer.response: No. In fact, we always assume that every measurement is done carefully. If you do a measurement and realize that you were not careful enough you shouldn't record the result - you should discard it. So the amount of caution has little to do with the precision. The precision is determined by the measurement process, and the tools used.

answer.answer_text: No. It is possible that you've made a mistake such as misreading the stopwatch.
answer.response: No. This is why we normally do measurements multiple times. Measurements that involved mistakes usually "stick out like a sore thumb" compared to the others and we discard them. The precision of a measurement has nothing to do with whether the person doing the measurement made a mistake. It is inherent to the measurement process, even if everything was done correctly.

answer.answer_text: No. The timing should be absolutely precise.
answer.response: No. There is no such thing as an absolutely precise measurement. It is inherent to all measurement processes that they have limited precision.

page.title: Which equation is dimensionally correct?
page.contents: Using the usual symbols (x for positions, v for velocities, a for accelerations, t for times) which equation below is dimensionally correct?

answer.response: Yes. That gives (m/s)^2/s = m/s^2
No. That gives a right hand side of m^2/s^3 which is not correct units for an acceleration.
No. The right side of the equation has units of m/s^3 which are not correct units for an acceleration.
No. The right side of the equation has units of 1/s^2 which is not correct units for an acceleration.
No. The right side of the equation has units of m^3/s^2, which is not correct for an acceleration.

page.title: Add numbers with sig. fig. rules. 1
page.contents:
Which of the answers below to the addition

1.234 m + 0.0179 m

is written using correct significant figures?

answer.response: Yes. 1.234 has 3 digits after the decimal and 0.0179 has 4. In this case the sig. fig. rule for addition says we round to 3 digits after the decimal.
No. We don't know the 4th digit after the decimal place for 1.234 m. So we don't know the 4th digit after the decimal place for the answer.

Have you mixed the rule up with the rule for multiplication? You have rounded to the number of sig. figs. of the number with fewer sig. figs. But the addition rule has to do with digits after the decimal place, not sig. figs.
No. Why have you rounded to just 2 significant figures? This isn't what any of the sig. fig. rules say to do.

No. We don't know the 4th digit after the decimal place of 1.234 m. So we don't know the 4th digit after the decimal place in the answer. We would only write the answer you chose if we knew that the 4th digit after the decimal place was a zero.

page.title: End of cluster 1-3
page.contents: End of cluster

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Choose correct 3A-2B (algebraic)
page.contents:
Suppose we have the two vectors:

\( \vec{a} = -4\hat{i} \)

\( \vec{b} = 2\hat{i} \)

Suppose also that the vector \( \vec{c} \) is \( \vec{c} = 3 \vec{a} - 2\vec{b} \)

Which of the following is the correct value for \( \vec{c} \)?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  The answer you chose is a lot like saying "aardvark = red".  The left side, \( \vec{c} \), is a vector, but the right side, \( -16 \), is a scalar.  A vector cannot equal a scalar.
No.  I think you might have dropped a negative somewhere in your calculation.
No.  The answer you chose is a lot like saying "aardvark = red".  The left side, \( \vec{c} \), is a vector, but the right side, \( -16 \), is a scalar.  A vector cannot equal a scalar.
No.  Notice that both vectors are parallel to the x-axis (we can tell this because they have no y-components).  So the answer must also be parallel to the x-axis.

page.title: give components of vector
page.contents: Get some practise.  Here is a vector and a coordinate system.  Express the vector in component form.

answer.response: Yes.
No.  Did you draw the triangle?  Look at the side which corresponds to the x-component.  Is it the opposite or the adjacent side to the 30 degree angle?
Look at the vector and the axes.  Decide what the signs of the components are before you reach for your calculator.

No.  Did you decide that both components of the vector are negative because the tail of the vector is in the 3rd quadrant?  But remember that you can "slide a vector around" without changing it.  The location of the tail of the vector is irrelevant.

Look at the vector.  It is drawn at roughly the angle claimed.  Which should be larger, the x-component or the y-component.  Now look at your calculator.  I think you will find that it is in radian mode.

Look at the vector.  It is drawn at roughly the angle claimed.  Which should be larger, the x-component or the y-component.  Now look at your calculator.  I think you will find that it is in radian mode.
Look at your calculator.  I think you will find that it is in radian mode.  Also, I think you are mixing up the two components.  Draw the triangle before trying to do the trig.

page.title: End of cluster 1-4
page.contents: End of cluster

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Cluster
page.contents: Cluster

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Write measurement with correct sig. figs. 2
page.contents:
We are doing an experiment in which a metal ball is shot out of a launcher and later collides with a pendulum (this is called a "ballistic pendulum experiment").  We have measured the speed of the ball leaving the launcher 9 times and have found a mean speed of 6.8137104 m/s with a standard deviation of 0.590137 m/s.

Which of the following is the correct way to write the experimentally determined speed of the ball as it leaves the launcher?

answer.response: Yes. You have used the SDOM as the uncertainty and you have rounded correctly.

There are two problems with this answer. One is that you've used the standard deviation as the uncertainty in the mean. But you should use the SDOM (it wasn't given but you can easily calculate it). The second problem is that you are not correctly applying the significant figures rules.
You are rounding correctly. But you have used the standard deviation as the uncertainty when you should be using the SDOM. The SDOM wasn't given but you can easily calculate it.
You have (correctly) used the SDOM as the uncertainty. But you haven't applied the rules for significant figures correctly.

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------First Half-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1104 - Response to Unit 1 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper and put your name in an upper corner of the page.  Write a big heading saying "First Half".  Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. In your own words, explain the difference between leading zeros and trailing zeros.  Which ones are significant figures?

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

------------End of Lesson-----------

You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after the first half of the lesson.

Under what you wrote for the first half of the lesson write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. Suppose we have a vector, \( \vec{a} \) which points parallel to the x-axis.  Further, suppose that it could point in either the positive x-direction or in the negative x-direction.  In your own words, explain the difference between the vector, \( \vec{a} \), its magnitude, \( a \), and its x-component, \( a_x \).

You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: give mag. dir. form - 2
page.contents:
Get some practise.  Here is a vector and a coordinate system with a grid. 

What are the magnitude and direction of this vector?

answer.response: Yes.
Almost.  But by convention an angle clockwise from the x-axis should be negative.
No.  You've forgotten how to use Pythagoras' Theorem to find the length of the hypotenuse of a triangle.
No.  You are looking at the location of the tip of the vector instead of looking at its components.  So you have used (4,1) as the coordinates of the vector.
No.  Look at your calculator.  Is it in radian mode?

page.title: Online Lecture 1.5: Vector Algebra (Part 2)
page.contents: In the previous video you saw how to get a vector's components from its magnitude and direction.  In this video we look at the reverse process of getting the magnitude and direction from the components.

page.contents: I will be asking you to do order of magnitude estimates on all of the assignments.  In this video I show a quick example of an order of magnitude estimate.

page.title: Changes in Level of Lake Mead
page.contents:
Here are the water levels in Lake Mead at three times.

June 1969: h = 1141.79 feet
June 1999: h = 1206.40 feet
June 2019: h = 1084.71 feet

Define \( \Delta h_1\) as the change in water level from 1969 to 1999. Define \(\Delta h_2\) as the change from 1999 to 2019. What are the values of \( \Delta h_1 \) and \( \Delta h_2 \)?

answer.response: Yes.
Look at the signs.  Remember that a change is a final value minus an initial value.
Look at the signs.  Remember that a change is a final value minus an initial value.
Look at the signs.  Remember that a change is a final value minus an initial value.
